title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others‚Äô private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement jeremy.wildfire@gilead.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla‚Äôs code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to the gsm Universe
text: Thank interest contributing gsm suite packages! repository follows centralized gsm Contributor Guidelines maintained gsm.core. Please review guidelines opening issues submitting pull requests.

title: Contributing to the gsm Universe
text: File issue opening pull request. Use appropriate issue template. Track issue gsm Roadmap Project Board. code changes made branch submitted PR following guidelines linked . detailed workflows (branching, releases, QC, CI/CD), please see full Contributor Guidelines gsm.core.

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: can install development version qcthat GitHub :

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: goal qcthat provide qualification report linking GitHub issues evidence issues implemented. break , minimum required steps {qcthat} implementation summarized . required step, additional (optional) configuration details core step described following sections. Throughout section üßë‚Äçüíº used indicate manual task, üíª used indicate automated tasks. File Issues üßë‚Äçüíº - Program developer documents feature/programming requirements using Github Issues. Write Code üßë‚Äçüíº - Program developer updates code associated documentation R package. Write Tests üßë‚Äçüíº - Quality Control Programmer writes needed tests includes link issue including Tests #{issue-number} test description. Release Package üíª - Upon GitHub release, tests automatically run summary report linking issues associated tests created attached release.

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: TL: Team Lead PD: Program Developer QCP: Quality Control Programmer USR: User Requester BR: Business Requirements

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: PD receives feature/programming request USR. PD documents feature/programming request USR using Github Issues. PD creates issue Business Requirement adds appropriate Tag (‚ÄúRequirement‚Äù). Issue name must label issue business requirement (e.g.¬†‚ÄúBusiness Requirement: {description}‚Äù). PD creates links separate issues sub-issues document technical requirements implementation details business requirement. Appropriate Type added (e.g., ‚ÄúFeature‚Äù, ‚ÄúTechnical Task‚Äù, ‚ÄúDocumentation Task‚Äù).

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: PD develops modifies program using user requirements. stakeholders (PD, TL, QCP USR) add comments reactions issue finalize scope needed. USR /TL documents approval business requirements via comment ‚Äúthumbs ‚Äù reaction needed. PD provides clear description changes every commit comment. developer chooses provide message addressing specific change, commit comment descriptive, concise, single-line summary change. context needed, PD add comment issue GitHub.

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: applicable, QCP PD defines automated test every applicable user requirement demonstrate information displayed report/application fit purpose meets stated requirement. Testing performed using common frameworks {testthat} {shinytest2} depending development process. Tests linked corresponding business requirements. Testing strategy requirement can documented updating Business Requirement GitHub issues referencing issue number commit message test code. Testing executed via automated services (GitHub Actions).

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: Upon completion code development testing, PD initiates Pull Request (PR). relevant issues tests linked PR. QCP determines appropriate level review. Verifies code /output user requirements documents method results. questions necessary code adjustments addressed process code review.

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: PD addressed required feedback, TL conducts final review code changes documentation. TL verifies tests passed, website successfully deployed (applicable), release pull request (PR) correctly targets primary branch. qualification program completed, QCP confirms documents result acceptance. Final acceptance utility program interactive report documented TL QCP formal approval Pull Request (PR) within SCM system. request approved, finalized code merged main code base ready release.

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: Upon acceptance, PD QCP creates formal release accordance established version control conventions. serves documentation equivalent program deployment production environment.

title: Lightweight quality control framework for R packages used in Clinical Trials
text: Contributions welcome! Creating utility package generalizable extensible sorts repository structures challenging, input greatly appreciated. submitting pull request, make sure file issue, generally fall one following categories: Bugfix: something broken. Feature: something wanted needed. QC: documentation metadata incorrect missing. New code generally follow tidyverse style guide.

title: Get rid of PRs in the issues list ‚Äî CompileIssuesDF
text: tibble::tibble() columns: Number: Issue number. Title: Issue title. Labels: List column character vectors issue labels. State: Issue state (open closed). StateReason: Reason issue state (e.g., completed) NA applicable. Milestone: Issue milestone title NA applicable. Type: Issue type NA applicable. Url: URL issue GitHub. ParentOwner: GitHub username organization name parent issue applicable, otherwise NA. ParentRepo: GitHub repository name parent issue applicable, otherwise NA. ParentNumber: GitHub issue number parent issue applicable, otherwise NA. CreatedAt: POSIXct timestamp issue created. ClosedAt: POSIXct timestamp issue closed, NA issue still open.

title: Extract information from testthat results ‚Äî CompileTestResults
text: tibble::tibble() columns: Description: desc field test testthat::test_that(). File: File test defined. Disposition: Factor levels pass, fail, skip indicating overall outcome test. IssueNumbers: List column containing integer vectors associated GitHub issue numbers.

title: Extract information from testthat results ‚Äî CompileTestResults
code: # Generate a test results object.  # lTestResults <- testthat::test_local(stop_on_failure = FALSE)  lTestResults <- structure(   list(     list(       file = "test-file1.R",       test = "First test with one GH issue (#32)",       results = list(         structure(           list(),           class = c("expectation_success", "expectation", "condition")         )       )     ),     list(       file = "test-file1.R",       test = "Second test with two GH issues (#32, #45)",       results = list(         structure(           list(),           class = c("expectation_failure", "expectation", "error", "condition")         )       )     )   ),   class = "testthat_results" ) CompileTestResults(lTestResults) #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 4 #>   Description                               File        Disposition IssueNumbers #>   <chr>                                     <chr>       <fct>       <list>       #> 1 First test with one GH issue (#32)        test-file1‚Ä¶ pass        <int [1]>    #> 2 Second test with two GH issues (#32, #45) test-file1‚Ä¶ fail        <int [2]>
